description: The <textarea> element represents an editing control that allows users to enter multi-line, free-form, plain text.
description_html: The <textarea> element represents an editing control that allows users to enter multi-line, free-form, plain text.
name: <textarea>

notes: Before Firefox 6, when a <textarea> was focused, the insertion point was placed at the end of the text by default. Other major browsers place the insertion point at the beginning of the text.
A default background-image gradient is applied to all <textarea> elements, which can be disabled using background-image: none.
Before Firefox 89, manipulating the content of <textarea> elements using Document.execCommand() commands requires workarounds (see bug 1220696).

Before Firefox for Android 6, when a <textarea> was focused, the insertion point was placed at the end of the text by default. Other major browsers place the insertion point at the beginning of the text.
A default background-image gradient is applied to all <textarea> elements, which can be disabled using background-image: none.
Before Firefox for Android 89, manipulating the content of <textarea> elements using Document.execCommand() commands requires workarounds (see bug 1220696).

safari_ios.notes: Unlike other major browsers, a default style of opacity: 0.4 is applied to disabled <textarea> elements.

webview_ios.notes: Unlike other major browsers, a default style of opacity: 0.4 is applied to disabled <textarea> elements.

safari.notes: Before Safari 17, newline characters counted as two characters instead of one. See bug 249916.

safari_ios.notes: Before Safari on iOS 17, newline characters counted as two characters instead of one. See bug 249916.

webview_ios.notes: Before WebView on iOS 17, newline characters counted as two characters instead of one. See bug 249916.
